entry.title: Combined summary - LN Summit 2023 Notes
entry.summary: The conversation during the Lightning Network protocol meeting covered various topics and proposals aimed at improving efficiency and simplifying processes. One proposal suggested storing unilateral closes in volatile RAM to be re-negotiated upon reconnection. The issue of static fees in the network was discussed, with conditional fees highlighted as a more suitable option in a demand-driven ecosystem.Reputation in the network was also raised as a topic of concern. Setting a minimum bar for attackers was identified as a challenge, and it was emphasized that reputation accumulation should align with normal node operation. The concept of jamming and its deviation from typical forwarding nodes was explored as well.Paying for the time a Hashed Time-Locked Contract (HTLC) is held in flight was considered, but the lack of a universal clock was acknowledged as a hurdle. Bitcoin chain height advances were mentioned as a potential universal clock, although their coarse-grained nature makes precise timing difficult.The issue of halting channel progress was addressed, suggesting that instead of a strict downgrade, a grace period could be negotiated to accommodate temporary halts due to software upgrades or connectivity issues.The discussions also covered various aspects of the Lightning Network protocol, including V3 transactions, Taproot upgrade, Gossip protocol versions, multi-sig channel parties, PTLCs, and channel jamming mitigation. Limiting the use of V3 transactions to unilateral closes was suggested, and the Taproot specifications were still in draft with notable changes. Different versions of the Gossip protocol were compared, with Gossip 1.5 favored for its inclusion of amount binding.Approaches for achieving multi-sig channel parties were explored, such as using scripts, FROSTy, and recursive musig. Two implementation methods for PTLCs were discussed: regular musig and adaptor signatures. Channel jamming mitigation solutions included monetary, reputation-based, and scarce resource-based approaches, with a hybrid approach combining unconditional fees and reputation systems considered the most promising.Versioning, async payments/trampoline, and communication within the Lightning Network community were also touched upon during the discussions. The meeting in New York City concluded with gratitude expressed towards those who attended, Wolf for hosting the event, and Michael Levin for assisting with note-taking.
